definition: to cross/to go over/to pass (time)/to celebrate (a holiday)/to live/to get along/excessively/too-
to remain/to be left/to have as remainder

sentences.english: In history, the overpopulation problem has never been so stand out like now.
sentences.chinese: 历史上，人口过剩的问题从来没有比现在更加突出。
产品滞销商品过剩意味什么？

sentences.english: If no overcapacity, it is clear that it is disgreeing with MIIT.
sentences.chinese: 如果说产能不过剩，摆明了是跟工信部唱反调。

sentences.english: Over-producing a commodity can lead to an economic crisis.
sentences.chinese: 商品生产过剩会导致经济危机。

sentences.english: This wave of excess density is sound.
sentences.chinese: 这种过剩密度的波就是声波。

sentences.english: The company's overgrown dealer network will be pruned.
sentences.chinese: 该公司过剩的经销商网络将得到修剪。

sentences.english: The over-supplying problem of building estates still exists now.
sentences.chinese: 楼盘的供应过剩的问题直到现在任然存在。

sentences.english: That has inevitably led to a large number of workers being laid off from overstaffed enterprises.
sentences.chinese: 此举无疑使人员过剩的企业有大量工人下岗。

sentences.english: Superfluous wealth can but superfluities only.
sentences.chinese: 过剩的财产只能购去过剩的工具。

sentences.english: Superfluous wealth can but superfluities only.
sentences.chinese: 过剩的财产只能购去过剩的工具。

sentences.english: Running is a good outlet for his energy.
sentences.chinese: 跑步是他发泄过剩精力的好方法。

sentences.english: Is he irrationally, overemotional, and reactive?
sentences.chinese: 他缺乏理性，情感过剩，反应强烈？

sentences.english: How about building a portfolio that avoids niches, industries and sectors where global overcapacity will create a profitless recovery?
sentences.chinese: 弄一个投资组合，规避那些过剩的行业，如何？

sentences.english: So these lead to more serious trend of "surplus management" and anti-efficiency in the society.
sentences.chinese: 由此，整个社会的“过剩管理”和反效率化倾向严重。

sentences.english: Over population, everyone has a job.
sentences.chinese: 人口过剩，但人人都有份工作。

sentences.english: Excess water will drain through sluices into the sea.
sentences.chinese: 过剩的水将会通过水闸排放到海里去。

definition: to furnish/to provide/supply (as in supply and demand)
property or cash held in reserve/stock
to decline/to fall/to drop/to falter/a decline/recession (in economics)
to be deficient in sth/to be short of sth (supplies, money etc)
to intensify/to sharpen/to accelerate/to aggravate/to exacerbate/to embitter
